questions.text: When you walk into an old city, what's your instinct?
options: Head straight for the oldest temple or ruin I can find
I'll check out the highlights, but I don't need to read every sign
I'd rather find a cool local café nearby
Old buildings kind of all look the same to me

questions.text: How do you feel about museums?
options: I could spend a whole day in one — history is fascinating
A couple of hours is enough for me
I only go if it's world-famous or very visual
I'd rather be outside than in a museum

questions.text: If a city has ancient ruins but is a bit hard to get around, would you still go?
options: Absolutely — that's exactly the kind of place I want
Yes, if the ruins are truly significant
Maybe, depends on how hard it really is
Probably not — I'd pick somewhere easier
Misty mountains, rice terraces, or a river winding through karst peaks
A dense forest trail or dramatic cliff viewpoint
A lively night market or colorful alley
A glittering skyline from a rooftop bar

questions.text: On a free afternoon, you'd rather…
options: Find a scenic hiking trail or lake to sit by
Wander through a village or countryside
Explore neighborhoods, shops, and street food
Hit a mall, art gallery, or trendy urban spot

questions.text: After a full day of exploring, where do you feel most recharged?
options: On a quiet mountain trail or lakeside meadow with only natural sounds
In a mellow small town with trees, cafés, and a slower rhythm
In a compact city district where every turn reveals a new food stall or gallery
Under a glittering skyline at a rooftop bar or neon night market

questions.text: You're at a local restaurant with no English menu and no pictures. You…
options: Pull out Google Translate and point at random — this is the fun part
Try to figure it out, maybe ask a local for help
Look for something recognizable, play it safe
Quietly look for another restaurant with photos

questions.text: You arrive at a busy transit hub where almost everything is in Chinese. You…
options: Treat it like a fun puzzle and figure it out step by step
Use maps/translation tools and adapt quickly
Feel stressed and try to find English help first
Change plans immediately to somewhere easier to navigate
A family-run guesthouse where you eat breakfast with the owners
A local boutique hotel with some character
A reliable international chain hotel
A well-known international brand — I know exactly what I'm getting

questions.text: How do you typically plan a trip?
options: A loose idea of where I'm going — I'll figure it out as I go
A rough framework, but lots of flexibility
A solid itinerary with key sites planned in advance
Every day mapped out — I don't want to waste a minute

questions.text: By day 3 of a trip, you're usually…
options: Still on day 1's vibe — I found a spot I love and I'm staying
Taking it easy, letting the city come to me
Moving through my list but taking breaks
Already thinking about what I might have missed and how to fit more in

questions.text: You only have one full day left in a city. You…
options: Pack the day with as many spots as possible from morning to night
Plan 3-4 must-sees and keep a steady pace
Pick 1-2 highlights and leave plenty of downtime
Keep the day mostly open and move slowly with no checklist

questions.text: What's your ideal evening on a trip?
options: A rooftop bar, meeting other travelers, staying out late
A lively local restaurant with good food and buzz around me
A quiet dinner at a place with great atmosphere
In my room, decompressing with a book or show

questions.text: At dinner, a local traveler at the next table starts chatting with you. You…
options: Jump right in and turn it into a real conversation
Chat for a while if the vibe feels natural
Respond politely but keep it brief
Smile, nod, and return to your own space quickly
A wild nightlife scene and always something going on
A social but not overwhelming energy
A calm, pleasant atmosphere
Peaceful streets where I can hear myself think

questions.text: How do you feel about going somewhere most tourists skip?
options: That's exactly why I'd go there
Exciting, if I know there's something worth seeing
A bit nervous, but I'd consider it
I prefer places with a clear tourist trail — it's easier and safer

questions.text: You show up and your original plan falls through. Your reaction?
options: Great — now I'll discover something I never would have planned
Annoyed at first, but I'd adapt quickly
Pretty stressed — I'd work hard to fix the plan
This is why I over-plan everything
A village accessible only by a 3-hour boat ride
A hidden local neighborhood most tourists never find
A famous landmark, done properly with good context
A well-organized tour that covers all the highlights efficiently
